data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: fit Christmas tree toys (polygon shapes) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum of (side^2/N) for all N. Lower is better. Target: 68.922808

Tree shape is a 15-vertex polygon with trunk (0.15 wide, 0.2 tall) and 3-tier triangular top (base 0.7, mid 0.4, top 0.25 wide). Total height ~1.0 (from -0.2 to 0.8). Trees can be rotated and positioned.

Key optimization techniques from top kernels: 1) Simulated Annealing with high temperature, 2) Squeeze (scale toward center), 3) Compaction (move trees toward center), 4) Local search (small position/rotation adjustments), 5) Swap moves, 6) Backward propagation (remove trees from N+1 config to get N config)

C++ implementation is critical for speed - kernels use OpenMP parallelization, long double precision, and optimized polygon overlap detection (bounding box check + point-in-polygon + segment intersection)
Backward propagation: Start from N=200, remove boundary-touching trees one by one to potentially improve smaller N configurations. This leverages good packings from larger N.
